conclusion: To determine the temperature of the gas in state D, analyze the processes from state A to state D.
A to B is an isobaric process; B to C is an isothermal process; C to D is an isochoric process.
Pressure remains constant at 4 atm from A to B; Volume increases from 10 L to 20 L.
Using ideal gas law, relate temperatures at A and B: V_A/T_A = V_B/T_B.
Temperature remains constant at 600 K from B to C; Pressure decreases from 4 atm to 2 atm; Volume increases from 20 L to 40 L.
Volume remains constant at 40 L from C to D; Pressure decreases from 2 atm to 2 atm (no change).
Since volume is constant, P ‚àù T; P_C/T_C = P_D/T_D.
Given P_C = P_D = 2 atm and T_C = 600 K, find T_D = 600 K.
The temperature of the gas in state D is 600 K.
